abstract: Foreign policy experts and critics contend appointment of media executive Andrew Lack as first chief executive of Broadcasting Board of Governors will turn dysfunctional agency around in shaping world opinion about United States; say board helmed by Lack, former president of NBC News, will better challenge increasingly hostile views of Americans abroad and more vigorously compete with rivals in information battle.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Lack, the first chief executive of the Broadcasting Board of Governors, represents a sea change for the agency, which oversees United States government-supported civilian international news media.
snippet: Andrew Lack, the first chief executive of the Broadcasting Board of Governors, represents a sea change for the agency, which oversees United States government-supported civilian international news media.

headline.main: U.S. Seeking a Stronger World Media Voice
headline.seo: Broadcasting Board of Governors Names Chief Executive
headline.print_headline: U.S. Looks to Reshape Media Image Abroad
